item.title: Report E-2025010254
item.description:
Report E-2025010254

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-31T00:56:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-17
  • City: EDGEWOOD
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On January 17, 2025, one (1) 55-gallon drum of heptane was damaged and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer and gravel beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Works, Inc. (EWI) to remediate the impacted site. The crew overpacked the damaged drum in one (1) 95-gallon drum. The crew utilized absorbent pads and granular absorbents to clear the areas. All waste was containerized in one (1) 16-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report X-2025010968
item.description:
Report X-2025010968

Identified by scraper @ 2025-01-31T00:56:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-05
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Chicago Central and Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 18000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On Sunday, January 5th, 2025, a CN mechanical performing an inspection observed that the bottom outlet valve appeared to be leaking from tank car # SHQX 70932 along with a strong Ethanol type odor in the area. The employee notified the Waterloo Yard Master who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The tank car was set out to an isolation track (WA90) for inspection by a CN emergency response contractor. A CN emergency response contractor was dispatched to the location for mitigation. The contractor performed an inspection of the tank car and found the bottom outlet valve to be leaking from the threads of the bottom outlet valve cap. (The BOV cap was found to be less than tool tight and the BOV handle was disengaged and pinned upon initial inspection). Also, the car seal provision indicator was not properly engaged according to the BOV diagram provided on the car. Cap was tightened and the BOV valve was inspected. The BOV valve handle was cycled exposing the valve was in the open position. The BOV cap was then removed and observed for 20 minutes to ensure there was no further leakage from the valve. The BOV cap gasket was replaced. The bottom outlet valve cap was then re-installed and tightened with a 36" pipe wrench. Upon tightening the BOV cap, CN emergency response contractor proceeded to place new cable seals on the BOV / Cap. Position
